ground_1.title: Landlord Previously Occupied as Only or Principal Home
ground_1.shortDescription: The landlord who is seeking possession or, in the case of joint landlords, at least one of them occupied the dwelling-house as his only or principal home at some time before the beginning of the tenancy.
ground_1.fullLegalText:
Not later than the beginning of the tenancy the landlord gave notice in writing to the tenant that possession might be recovered on this ground or the court is of the opinion that it is just and equitable to dispense with the requirement of notice and (in either case)—
(a) at some time before the beginning of the tenancy, the landlord who is seeking possession or, in the case of joint landlords seeking possession, at least one of them occupied the dwelling-house as his only or principal home; or
(b) the landlord who is seeking possession or, in the case of joint landlords seeking possession, at least one of them requires the dwelling-house as his or his spouse's only or principal home and neither the landlord (or, in the case of joint landlords, any one of them) nor any other person who, as landlord, derived title under the landlord who gave the notice mentioned above acquired the reversion on the tenancy for money or money's worth.
ground_1.statute: Housing Act 1988, Schedule 2, Part I, Ground 1
ground_1.notice_required: Yes - written notice before or at start of tenancy
ground_1.court_decision: Mandatory - court must grant possession if ground proven
required_evidence: Written notice given to tenant before/at start of tenancy
Proof landlord lived in property before tenancy (utility bills, council tax, etc.)
OR proof landlord now requires property as only/principal home
common_defences: No written notice was given before tenancy started
Landlord did not actually live in property before tenancy
Landlord purchased property specifically for investment
ground_1.notes: Notice requirement can be waived if court finds it 'just and equitable'. Commonly used when landlord had to relocate temporarily and wants to return.

ground_2.title: Mortgage Lender Requires Possession
ground_2.shortDescription: The dwelling-house is subject to a mortgage granted before the beginning of the tenancy and the mortgagee requires possession to dispose of the dwelling-house.
ground_2.fullLegalText:
Not later than the beginning of the tenancy the landlord gave notice in writing to the tenant that possession might be recovered on this ground or the court is of the opinion that it is just and equitable to dispense with the requirement of notice and the dwelling-house is subject to a mortgage granted before the beginning of the tenancy and—
(a) the mortgagee is entitled to exercise a power of sale conferred on him by the mortgage or by section 101 of the Law of Property Act 1925; and
(b) the mortgagee requires possession of the dwelling-house for the purpose of disposing of it with vacant possession in exercise of that power; and
(c) either notice was given as mentioned above or the court is satisfied that the mortgagee is likely to suffer financial hardship unless the court gives such directions.
ground_2.statute: Housing Act 1988, Schedule 2, Part I, Ground 2
ground_2.notice_required: Yes - written notice before or at start of tenancy
required_evidence: Written notice given before/at start of tenancy
Mortgage agreement predating tenancy
Letter from lender requiring possession
Evidence lender entitled to exercise power of sale
common_defences: No written notice given
Mortgage granted after tenancy started
Lender not genuinely requiring possession
ground_2.notes: Usually arises when landlord defaults on mortgage. Lender must prove entitlement to exercise power of sale.

ground_8.title: Serious Rent Arrears
ground_8.shortDescription: Both at the date of the service of the notice and at the date of the hearing at least 8 weeks' rent is unpaid (2 months for monthly tenancy).
ground_8.statute: Housing Act 1988, Schedule 2, Part I, Ground 8
ground_8.court_decision: Mandatory - court must grant possession if arrears proven
required_evidence: Rent account showing arrears
Proof of rent amount and payment schedule
Calculation showing 8 weeks/2 months arrears at notice date
Calculation showing 8 weeks/2 months arrears at hearing date
common_defences: Arrears reduced below threshold before hearing
Rent not lawfully due (e.g., disrepair reduces rent owed)
Calculation incorrect
Counterclaim for disrepair
ground_8.notes: Most powerful eviction ground for landlords. Arrears must meet threshold at BOTH notice and hearing dates. If arrears drop below threshold before hearing, ground fails.

ground_10.title: Some Rent Arrears
ground_10.shortDescription: Some rent lawfully due from the tenant is unpaid on the date on which proceedings for possession are begun and was in arrears at the date of service of the notice.
ground_10.fullLegalText:
Some rent lawfully due from the tenant—
(a) is unpaid on the date on which the proceedings for possession are begun; and
(b) except where subsection (1)(b) of section 8 of this Act applies, was in arrears at the date of the service of the notice under that section relating to those proceedings.
ground_10.statute: Housing Act 1988, Schedule 2, Part II, Ground 10
ground_10.court_decision: Discretionary - court may grant possession if reasonable
required_evidence: Rent account showing any amount unpaid
Proof arrears existed at notice date
Proof arrears still exist at hearing date
common_defences: Arrears paid in full before hearing
Small amount - not reasonable to evict
Tenant has reasonable excuse for non-payment
Landlord failed to maintain property (disrepair)
Tenant can afford to pay ongoing rent plus affordable arrears installments
ground_10.notes: Court will consider reasonableness. Small arrears, payment plan in place, or tenant's personal circumstances may prevent possession. Often used with Ground 8 as backup.

ground_11.title: Persistent Delay in Paying Rent
ground_11.shortDescription: Whether or not any rent is in arrears on the date on which proceedings for possession are begun, the tenant has persistently delayed paying rent which has become lawfully due.
ground_11.statute: Housing Act 1988, Schedule 2, Part II, Ground 11
required_evidence: Detailed rent account showing pattern of late payments
Evidence of multiple late payment instances over time
Communication with tenant about late payments
common_defences: Rent paid in full - no arrears
Late payments due to benefit payment dates
Landlord accepted late payments without complaint
Recent payment record improved
ground_11.notes: Persistent means a repeated pattern, not isolated incidents. Can succeed even if no arrears at hearing. Court considers full circumstances.

ground_12.title: Breach of Tenancy Obligation
ground_12.shortDescription: Any obligation of the tenancy (other than one related to the payment of rent) has been broken or not performed.
ground_12.fullLegalText: Any obligation of the tenancy (other than one related to the payment of rent) has been broken or not performed.
ground_12.statute: Housing Act 1988, Schedule 2, Part II, Ground 12
required_evidence: Copy of tenancy agreement showing obligation
Evidence of breach (photos, witness statements, etc.)
Communication with tenant about breach
Proof breach is ongoing or unremedied
common_defences: Breach remedied before hearing
Clause in tenancy is unfair/unenforceable
Minor breach - not reasonable to evict
Landlord waived breach by accepting it previously
ground_12.notes: Common breaches: keeping pets, subletting, business use. Must be material breach. Court considers whether tenant remedied breach.

ground_13.title: Deterioration of Dwelling
ground_13.shortDescription: The condition of the dwelling-house or any of the common parts has deteriorated owing to acts of waste by, or the neglect or default of, the tenant or any other person residing in the dwelling-house.
ground_13.fullLegalText: The condition of the dwelling-house or any of the common parts has deteriorated owing to acts of waste by, or the neglect or default of, the tenant or any other person residing in the dwelling-house and, in the case of an act of waste by, or the neglect or default of, a person lodging with the tenant or a sub-tenant of his, the tenant has not taken such steps as he ought reasonably to have taken for the removal of the lodger or sub-tenant.
ground_13.statute: Housing Act 1988, Schedule 2, Part II, Ground 13
required_evidence: Inventory and condition report from start of tenancy
Photographs of current condition
Expert report on damage/deterioration
Evidence linking damage to tenant/resident actions
common_defences: Damage is normal wear and tear
Deterioration due to landlord's failure to maintain/repair
Damage caused by third party not residing at property
Damage already existed at start of tenancy
ground_13.notes: Must prove deterioration beyond normal wear and tear. If caused by lodger/subtenant, must show tenant failed to act reasonably to remove them.

ground_14.title: Nuisance or Annoyance
ground_14.shortDescription: The tenant or any other person residing in or visiting the dwelling-house has been guilty of conduct causing or likely to cause a nuisance or annoyance to a person residing, visiting or otherwise engaging in a lawful activity in the locality, or has been convicted of using the dwelling-house or allowing it to be used for immoral or illegal purposes, or an arrestable offence committed in, or in the locality of, the dwelling-house.
ground_14.fullLegalText:
The tenant or a person residing in or visiting the dwelling-house—
(a) has been guilty of conduct causing or likely to cause a nuisance or annoyance to a person residing, visiting or otherwise engaging in a lawful activity in the locality, or
(b) has been convicted of—
(i) using the dwelling-house or allowing it to be used for immoral or illegal purposes, or
(ii) an arrestable offence committed in, or in the locality of, the dwelling-house.
ground_14.statute: Housing Act 1988, Schedule 2, Part II, Ground 14
ground_14.notice_required: Yes - Section 8 notice (can be immediate in serious cases)
required_evidence: Witness statements from neighbors
Noise complaint reports
Police reports/crime numbers
Council noise monitoring records
Conviction records if applicable
Diary of incidents
common_defences: Allegations unproven
Isolated incident, not pattern of behavior
Nuisance has ceased
Complainants unreasonable
Criminal conviction was for minor matter
ground_14.notes: Covers antisocial behavior, noise nuisance, criminal activity. Can use immediate notice procedure in serious cases. Strong evidence from multiple neighbors increases success rate.

ground_14a.title: Domestic Violence
ground_14a.shortDescription: The dwelling-house was occupied (whether alone or with others) by a married couple or a couple who are civil partners of each other and one or both of them is a tenant and one partner has left because of violence or threats of violence from the other.
ground_14a.fullLegalText:
The dwelling-house was occupied (whether alone or with others) by a married couple or a couple who are civil partners of each other and—
(a) one or both of the partners is a tenant of the dwelling-house,
(b) the landlord who is seeking possession is a registered social landlord or a charitable housing trust,
(c) one partner has left the dwelling-house because of violence or threats of violence by the other towards—
(i) that partner, or
(ii) a member of the family of that partner who was residing with that partner immediately before the partner left, and
(d) the court is satisfied that the partner who has left is unlikely to return.
ground_14a.statute: Housing Act 1988, Schedule 2, Part II, Ground 14A
required_evidence: Evidence of domestic violence (police reports, restraining orders, medical records)
Evidence partner has left property
Statement from victim confirming unlikely to return
Witness statements if available
common_defences: Reconciliation possible
Allegations of violence unproven
Partner willing to return
ground_14a.notes: Primarily for social landlords. Allows possession against perpetrator. Requires clear evidence of domestic violence and that victim is unlikely to return.

ground_15.title: Deterioration of Furniture
ground_15.shortDescription: The condition of any furniture provided for use under the tenancy has deteriorated owing to ill-treatment by the tenant or any other person residing in the dwelling-house.
ground_15.fullLegalText: The condition of any furniture provided for use under the tenancy has, in the opinion of the court, deteriorated owing to ill-treatment by the tenant or any other person residing in the dwelling-house and, in the case of ill-treatment by a person lodging with the tenant or by a sub-tenant of his, the tenant has not taken such steps as he ought reasonably to have taken for the removal of the lodger or sub-tenant.
ground_15.statute: Housing Act 1988, Schedule 2, Part II, Ground 15
required_evidence: Furniture inventory from start of tenancy
Photographs of furniture condition
Expert assessment of damage
Evidence linking damage to ill-treatment vs. fair wear and tear
common_defences: Damage is fair wear and tear
Furniture was poor quality/second-hand
Damage existed before tenancy
Tenant has offered to repair/replace
ground_15.notes: Rarely used alone - usually combined with other grounds. Must prove ill-treatment beyond normal wear and tear.

ground_17.title: False Statement
ground_17.shortDescription: The tenancy was induced by a false statement made knowingly or recklessly by the tenant or a person acting at the tenant's instigation.
ground_17.fullLegalText:
The tenancy was induced by a false statement made knowingly or recklessly by—
(a) the tenant, or
(b) a person acting at the tenant's instigation.
ground_17.statute: Housing Act 1988, Schedule 2, Part II, Ground 17
required_evidence: Copy of tenancy application/reference
Evidence showing statement was false
Proof tenant made statement knowingly or recklessly
Evidence statement influenced decision to grant tenancy
common_defences: Statement was true at time made
Honest mistake, not knowingly false
Statement not material to grant of tenancy
Landlord did not rely on statement
ground_17.notes: Common examples: false employment details, fake references, concealing criminal record. Must prove statement was material and knowingly/recklessly false.

no_fault_possession.title: Section 21 - No Fault Possession
no_fault_possession.description: Landlord seeking possession without needing to prove fault
no_fault_possession.status: Being phased out - Renters Reform Bill will abolish Section 21

deposit_protection.requirement: Deposit protected in government-approved scheme within 30 days
deposit_protection.consequence_if_fail: Section 21 notice invalid + tenant can claim 1-3x deposit penalty

prescribed_information.requirement: Prescribed information given to tenant within 30 days of receiving deposit

gas_safety.requirement: Gas Safety Certificate provided at start of tenancy and annually

epc.requirement: Energy Performance Certificate provided, minimum rating E
epc.consequence_if_fail: Section 21 notice invalid + cannot legally let property

how_to_rent.requirement: How to Rent government booklet provided at start of tenancy
how_to_rent.valid_version: Must be most recent version at time of tenancy start

licensing.requirement: Property must be properly licensed if HMO or selective licensing area
licensing.consequence_if_fail: Section 21 notice invalid + criminal offence + rent repayment order

prohibited_fees.requirement: No prohibited fees charged under Tenant Fees Act 2019
prohibited_fees.consequence_if_fail: Section 21 notice invalid until fees repaid

retaliatory_eviction.requirement: Not served within 6 months of tenant requesting repairs or complaining to local authority

timing.requirement: Cannot be served in first 4 months of tenancy
